questionText: What is a coronavirus?
answerText: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses. There are different types of coronaviruses.  Some types of coronavirus are more common in people and some versions are more common in animals. Rarely, a type of the virus that was common in animals can spread to people. "Coronavirus Disease 2019” (which is shortened to "COVID-19") is an example of a type of coronavirus that has recently spread to humans.     [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is novel (new) coronavirus?]]

questionText: What is novel (new) coronavirus?
answerText: A "novel" virus means that scientists haven't seen this type of the virus before.  "Coronavirus Disease 2019” which is shortened to "COVID-19" is type of a virus that has never been seen before in humans. This means that the body needs to learn how to fight off this new type of virus.  [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionText: What is COVID-19?
answerText: COVID-19 is a disease caused by a new type of virus. Sometimes people also call it "coronavirus," which is is the type of virus that causes COVID-19. COVID-19 causes some symptoms that are like getting a cold or flu. But some people get worse symptoms and need more care. COVID-19 is caused by a new type of virus that our body has not seen before. Since our body has not seen it before, our immune system has to learn how to fight off this new virus.     [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: Why is it called COVID-19?
answerText: COVID-19 stands for corona (CO), virus (VI), disease (D). The number "19" means it was first found in the year 2019.   [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionText: What is SARS-CoV-2?
answerText: SARS-COV-2 is the name for the virus that causes the disease known as "COVID-19." Let's break it down.  "SARS" stands for "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome", meaning that it can cause serious problems with breathing and the lungs.    "COV" stands for "Coronavirus." This is the type of virus that causes COVID-19.   The "2" is a way to say that this virus is different than the SARS virus that caused an outbreak in 2002-2003.   [[Would you like more information about why there are two names for COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about what is the difference between COVID-19 and SARS-CoV-2?]] [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronovirus?]]

questionText: Why are there two names for COVID-19?
answerText: SARS-CoV-2 is the name for the virus that causes COVID-19. SARS-CoV-2 is usually used when people talk about making new tests, vaccines, and medicines.  COVID-19 is the name of the disease itself. COVID-19 is usually used when people talk about the disease's spread, prevention, symptoms, and treatment.  [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]] [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV-2?]] [[Would you like more information about Why is it called COVID-19?]]

questionText: What is the difference between COVID-19 and SARS-CoV-2?
answerText: SARS-CoV-2 is the name for the virus that causes COVID-19. SARS-CoV-2 is usually used when people talk about making new tests, vaccines, and medicines.  COVID-19 is the name of the disease itself. COVID-19 is usually used when people talk about the disease's spread, prevention, symptoms, and treatment.  [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]] [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV-2?]] [[Would you like more information about Why is it called COVID-19?]]

questionText: What is MERS-CoV?
answerText: MERS-CoV is one type of coronavirus. It is different type from the type of coronavirus that causes COVID-19. MERS-CoV stands for "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome- associated Coronavirus."  The first cases of MERS-CoV were seen in 2012 in Saudi Arabia. MERS-CoV symptoms are fever, cough, and shortness of breath. People with this disease usually do not get sick from one another unless they are in very close contact.  [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV-2?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionText: What is SARS-CoV?
answerText: SARS-CoV stands for "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-associated CoronaVirus." It is a virus that can cause serious problems with breathing and the lungs. It is different from the virus that has caused the COVID-19 pandemic.   The SARS-CoV virus was first found in Asia in 2003 and last known human case was in China in 2004. SARS-CoV spreads through close person to person contact and caused flu like symptoms.   [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV-2?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionText: What caused COVID-19?
answerText: All blood donors are required to be in good health and have a normal body temperature on the day of donation. People with COVID-19 will not be allowed to donate blood.  Donors are told to contact the donor center if they become sick after donation, so that their donation will not be used. Even when a donor has COVID-19 after donation, there have been no cases of COVID-19 linked to their blood.

questionText: When and where did it start?
answerText: The first case was found in Wuhan City, Hubei Province, China in late December 2019. The virus was thought to have spread from an animal to a human. Now, the virus is able to spread from person to person.

questionText: Will COVID-19 weaken over time?
answerText: In general, virus's genetic material can change over time. However, there is no guarantee these changes will make the virus weaker. We can not predict if the virus causing COVID-19 will become weak with time.

questionText: When is COVID-19 going to stop?
answerText: Unfortunately, we do not know when COVID-19 will stop. Right now, to protect yourself and others from getting sick, you should:  -Practice social distancing -Stay at home as much as possible,  -Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds -Follow the guidelines of your local and state health department for what actvities are allowed -If you do have to go out, maintain a 6-foot physical distance between yourself and others.   [[Would like more information about how to protect yourself and your family?]] [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionText: What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?
answerText: The most important thing is to wash your hands. Use soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, or before or after eating or making food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands look dirty. If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol.     Here are some other things you can do to reduce your risk of getting COVID-19:    - Clean and disinfect surfaces that you touch a lot, like tables, counters, light switches, door knobs, and cabinet handles.   - Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues and throw the tissue away.   - Stay at home if you are sick.   - Don't get too close to people who are sick.   - If "social distancing" measures are in effect where you are, be sure to follow them.     [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]   [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionText: What is a virus?
answerText: A virus is a very small particle that infect other cells. Viruses that infect people can make them sick.  Viruses are tiny, smaller than bacteria or fungi. They are small pieces of genetic material (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein shell. Viruses cannot survive long on their own. They need to use a living cell to live and reproduce. Once a virus enters a cell, it takes over that cell and uses it to make more viruses that go on to infect other cells.  [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionText: Why is COVID-19 dangerous?
answerText: There are a few reasons why people are very concerned about COVID-19. First, it is a new virus that humans have never had before. Our bodies haven't learned how to fight it off yet. Second, the virus is very infectious and has spread quickly around the world. Third, about 1 out of every 5 people who gets COVID-19 needs medical care in a hospital. Some hospitals will have trouble caring for this many sick people at the same time. Fourth, doctors and scientists still don't know very much about COVID-19 or how to treat it yet. Everyone is learning more every day.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for serious illness?]]

questionText: What does a COVID-19 cell look like?
answerText: Please click here to see what the COVID-19 cell looks like: https://www.cdc.gov/media/subtopic/images.htm

questionText: Is the virus manufactured or naturally occuring?
answerText: The virus that caused COVID-19 most likely came from animals and then started to spread to people.  Scientists who have studied the virus's DNA think that it is unlikely that the virus was made in a laboratory or manufactured.  [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]] [[Would you like more informabout about What is SARS-CoV-2?]]

questionText: Is there more than one strain of COVID-19?
answerText: Right now, scientists think there are two main types (or strains) of the new coronavirus. This is based on an analysis of 103 cases. To read the original article, please click here: https://academic.oup.com/nsr/advance-article/doi/10.1093/nsr/nwaa036/5775463   [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV-2?]]

questionText: What is the difference between a bacteria and a virus?
answerText: An N95 respirator is a respiratory protective device designed to achieve a very close facial fit and very efficient filtration of airborne particles. It requires a fit test to make sure the mask create an adequate seal on your face.   The 'N95' designation means that when subjected to careful testing, the respirator blocks at least 95 percent of very small (0.3 micron) test particle

questionText: What is the difference between a pandemic and epidemic?
answerText: A pandemic is a global outbreak of disease that affects many people in different places.  An epidemic is an outbreak in a certain area or among a specific group of people over a particular period of time.   [[Would you like more information about Why did the World Health Organization (WHO) declare this a pandemic?]]

questionText: Why did the World Health Organization (WHO) declare this a pandemic?
answerText: The World Health Organization, or WHO, declared the COVID-19 outbreak to be a pandemic because it was likely that the virus was going to spread to all countries in the world. Declaring COVID-19 to be a pandemic helps to alert countries to prepare for the virus.   [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between a pandemic and epidemic?]]

questionText: Why are the death rates so different across countries?
answerText: The death rates are different between countries for a few reasons. The main reason is because some countries have tested more people than others.   Death rates can seem higher in countries where fewer people are tested. That's because death rates compare the number of people who have died from a disease to the number of people who have the disease, whether they die or not. When countries only test patients who are sick enough to go to the hospital and are not testing those who are less sick, this makes death rates seem higher than they are.

questionText: When will [COUNTRY] reach their peak?
answerText: To see when a country is likely to reach its "peak" number of COVID-19 cases, you can visit the website linked below to view the projected epidemic curves: https://covid19.healthdata.org/

questionText: Has COVID-19 mutated?
answerText: Like most viruses, the virus that causes COVID-19 is also mutating, which means changing its RNA structure. It is normal for viruses to mutate.  Right now, the mutations are probably not changing how the virus spreads or makes people sick.

questionText: Can you smoke weed/cannabis during COVID-19?
answerText: One danger for people who smoke cigarettes is that they could transfer the virus from their fingers or contaminated cigarettes to the lips. This could also happen for people who smoke weed or cannabis.  As for the effect of CBD and cannabis, right now we don’t have any studies showing if it affects coronovirus.

questionText: Will humanity survive COVID-19?
answerText: Together, we will survive COVID-19! Scientists and doctors are working very hard to find treatments and vaccines to help protect people from this virus.

questionText: What is the impact of COVID-19?
answerText: COVID-19 is likely impact our lives in many ways. On the community level, this oubreak might lead to a decrease in polarization, more trust in science, and less individualism. On a lifestyle-level, this outbreak has moved even more of our activities online and might be a new boon to virtual reality. In terms of our health, there is likely to be a rise on telemedicine and an opening stronger family care. It is quite obvious that the global economy has taken a big toll due to COVID-19. Some experts say that there will be more restraints on mass consumption, stronger domestic supply chains, and a widening of the inequality gap, following the pandemic.

questionText: Will COVID-19 go away like the 1918 influenza and SARS did?
answerText: There is a lot left to be learned about this virus and whether it will go away like past outbreaks. However, since we do not have vaccines and effective treatments, the best thing we can do is to practice social distancing and to take care of ourselves.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionText: How many asymptomatic people are there globally?
answerText: It is hard to know how many asymptomatic people there are in the world. As of now, it seems that many people who are infected may not show symptoms.

questionText: What are respiratory droplets?
answerText: Respiratory droplets are little drops that come from your nose or mouth when you sneeze, cough, talk, or breathe. They can stay in the air, or they can be passed from one person to another by touching commonly used surfaces such as door knobs, elevator buttons and faucets.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionText: How does COVID-19 spread?
answerText: COVID-19 can spread in a few different ways. It can spread from person to person if you inhale an infected person's respiratory droplets when they sneezes, coughs, or talk. It can also spead if you touch something that an infected person has touched, like a door knob, elevator button, or bathroom faucet.  That's why it's important to wash your hands, avoid touching your face, and practice social distancing to avoid getting sick. That's why it's also important to self-isolate and wear a mask around other household members if you are sick to avoid infecting other people.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about Does hand-washing kill the virus?]]

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services  https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/how-covid-spreads.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fprepare%2Ftransmission.html
questionText: Can COVID-19 be transmitted when a person is not showing symptoms?
answerText: People might be able to spread the disease before people realize they are sick. But most scientists think that people are most likely to infect others when they have symptoms and feel sick.   Canada public health services is doing research to try to answer this question.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionText: Does COVID-19 transfer through the air?
answerText: Yes. We are still learning about how easily COVID-19 can transfer through the air. Small droplets can probably stay in the air for a short time after someone coughs or sneezes and those could infect someone. Also, some medical procedures can cause very small droplets that stay in the air for a longer time.  Scientists think that the main way you could get infected is if you were in close contact with an infected person and had your mouth, nose, or eyes exposed to infected respiratory droplets.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What are respiratory droplets?]]

questionText: How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?
answerText: In an experiment, scientists found that the virus could live:  -On plastic for up to 72 hours (3 days) -On stainless steel for up to 48 hours (2 days) -On cardboard for up to 24 hours (1 day) -On copper for up to 4 hours -In the air for up to 3 hours  Scientists still need to do more research to find out if these results also apply to the real world.  It is important to clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot.You should also wash your hands frequently with soap and water or use a hand sanitizer with at leat 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionText: What is community spread?
answerText: Community spread means people have been infected with the virus in an area, including some who are not sure how or where they became infected.  [[Would you like more information about Is there COVID-19 in my area?]]

questionText: What is "flattening the curve"?
answerText: Flattening the curve means using socially distancing to prevent too many people from getting sick with COVID-19 at the same time. This helps to prevent the health care system from running out of enough staff and resources to care for everyone.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionText: Why do I have to "socially distance"?
answerText: Social distancing helps to reduce the chance of infecting people who are more likely to get severe disease. It helps to stop the virus from spreading quickly. This also helps to prevent there being too many sick people for hospitals to handle.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: Why do I have to stay at home?
answerText: Staying at home and using "social distancing" helps stop the virus from spreading quickly. This helps to reduce the burden on healthcare systems, as there are not enough hospital workers and beds if too many people get sick at once.  Social distancing means staying farther away from other people and avoiding groups of people. Since COVID-19 mostly spreads from person-to-person interactions, staying at least 6 feet away from other people can help stop the spread. It is important to use social distancing because people can spread COVID-19 even if they feel fine. It is especially important to use social distancing to protect people who are more likely to get very sick from the disease.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionText: What is self-isolation?
answerText: Self-isolation means that people who are sick stay away from those who are not sick. This helps to keep the disease from spreading. If someone has asked you to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you have to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands a lot -Keep track of your symptoms  Go here to read more about how you should self-isolate, visit this page: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html   [[Would you like more information about What is social-distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: What is self-monitoring?
answerText: Self-monitoring means that people should monitor themselves for fever by taking their temperatures twice a day and paying attention if they begin coughing or have trouble breathing. If they start to get symptoms during this self-monitoring period, they should self-isolate, limit their contact with others, and seek medical advice by telephone if possible.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionText: What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?
answerText: The difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation is based on whether you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 or not. If you may have been exposed to COVID-19 but don't have symptoms, you should self-monitor. If you have been diagnosed with COVID-19, you should self-isolate.  You need to self-monitor if you have no symptoms but may have been exposed to COVID-19 in the last 14 days or are in close contact with older adults, people who are medically vulnerable or have been asked to do so by your Public Health Authority. Self-monitoring means you should:  -Monitor yourself for 14 days for symptoms like fever, cough, and trouble breathing -Stay at home -Avoid crowded places -Stay at least 6 feet away from others as much as you can -Wash your hands frequently  You need to self-isolate if you have been confirmed to have COVID-19. Isolation means keeping infected people away from those who are not infected. If you have been asked to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you need to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands frequently -Keep checking your symptoms until your doctor says you don't need to be in isolation any more  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What should I do if I think I have COVID-19?]]

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionText: What is social distancing?
answerText: Social distancing means staying home and limiting contact with other people as much as you can. Social distancing is important because it reduces the spread of illness. You might need to change your habits to do social distancing well. For example:  -Avoid groups of people as much as you can -Don't shake hands or touch people to greet them -Don't go to crowded places such as concerts, arenas, conferences, or festivals -Stay away from people at high risk for severe symptoms, such as older people and those in poor health -Stay at least 2 arms' length (about 6 feet) away from others.  For example, if you need to buy groceries, limit this to once a week. If you go on walks, stay at least 6 feet away from others.

questionText: Should I wear a face mask?
answerText: Face masks, including fabric ones, are likely only helpful in preventing people who have COVID-19 from spreading it to others. If you wear a cloth mask, you should still use the same social distancing measures as you would if you were not wearing a mask. This means you should stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people, wash your hands frequently, and avoid touching your face or eyes.  When wearing a mask, make sure it covers your nose and mouth. Wash the mask after you use it every time. When handling the mask, act as though the front of the mask is contaminated. Don't touch the front of the mask when you take it off or put it on.  It is not recommended that the general public wear surgical or N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra surgical or N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?]]

questionText: What are N95 respirators/masks?
answerText: This is a type of personal protective equipment that forms a tight seal around the nose and mouth to avoid airborne particles and fluid from entering. These masks are not "one size fits all" so people who depend on them for the job must get fit-tested before using them.   It is not recommended that the general public wear  N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.  [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?]]

questionText: What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answerText: Personal protective equipment (PPE) are types of equipment worn to reduce the chance of someone getting a workplace injury or illness. Examples include gloves, safety glasses, shoes, earplugs or muffs, hard hats, respirators, coveralls, etc.   PPE is very important during this pandemic because there are not enough face masks for frontline health workers.  [[Would you like more information about What are N95 respirators/masks?]] [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]]

questionText: Is COVID-19 contagious?
answerText: COVID-19 is contagious and it is actively spreading from person to person. The CDC recommends that those who have COVID-19 are isolated either at a hospital or at home, depending on how sick they are, until they are no longer at risk of infecting others.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What is community spread?]]

questionText: How long are you contagious for if you have COVID-19?
answerText: We aren't sure exactly how long people are contagious from COVID-19. If you have been sick with COVID-19 and have been in isolation, you should talk to your healthcare provider to decide when you can be released from isolation. Your doctor will look for signs that:  -You are fever-free without taking fever-reducing medication -You no longer show symptoms -Sometimes, your doctor might recommend testing respiratory samples to decide if you can be released from isolation  Once you have been released from isolation, then you are no longer considered to be likely to infect other people.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: How long after being asymptomatic are you no longer contagious?
answerText: If you think that you've been exposed to COVID-19, and are asymptomatic, you should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks, from the time that you think you might have been exposed. That's because most people who get COVID-19 show symptoms within 14 days.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID-19?]]

questionText: How long do people have to isolate for?
answerText: How long you should be isolated for varies on a case-by-case basis. If you have been sick with COVID-19 and have been in isolation, you should talk to your healthcare provider to decide when you can be released from isolation. Your doctor will look for signs that:  -You are fever-free without taking fever-reducing medication -You no longer show symptoms -Sometimes, your doctor might recommend testing respiratory samples to decide if you can be released from isolation  Once you have been released from isolation, then you are no longer considered to be likely to infect other people.   [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: Is the virus infectious during incubation period?
answerText: Yes, the virus can spread from person to person during incubation period. The “incubation period” means the time between catching the virus and beginning to have symptoms of the disease. If you may have been exposed to the virus and do not have any symptoms, please self-quarantine. If you are having COVID-19 symptoms, please self-isolate.   [[Would you like more information about what is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about what is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about what are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: If you have been released from isolation, will you still be able to spread COVID-19 to others?
answerText: Once a person has been released from isolation by a medical provider, they are not considered to pose a risk to others.  [[Would you like more information about how contagious you are if you have COVID-19?]]

questionText: What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?
answerText: You need to self-isolate if you have been confirmed to have COVID-19. Isolation is a health care term that means keeping infected people away from those who are not infected. If you have been asked to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you need to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands frequently -Continue to monitor your symptoms until your doctor says you don't need to be in isolation any more  Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days. Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days.  [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: What does it mean to be isolated?
answerText: Self-isolation means that people who are sick stay away from those who are not sick. This helps to keep the disease from spreading. If someone has asked you to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you have to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands a lot -Keep track of your symptoms  Go here to read more about how you should self-isolate, visit this page: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about what does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?]]

questionText: What does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?
answerText: If the infected person lives with others, it is important to keep them apart from others as much as possible. This means they should stay in another room as much as they can and use a separate bedroom and bathroom if possible.  If you are living with someone who is infected, you should:  -Avoid sharing household items like dishes, cups, towels, and bedding -Wash your hands regularly or use hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol -Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot -Wash laundry frequently and thoroughly -If you have pets, the infected person should not care for them -Don't have visitors in your home

questionText: What is self-quarantine?
answerText: Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days.   Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days.

questionText: Can COVID-19 be spread through food (including refrigerated or frozen food)?
answerText: Current thinking is that COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person through respiratory droplets. Scientists are still studying how long coronavirus lives on surfaces. In general, you should practice good hygiene and food safety practices. This means cleaning surfaces that are used a lot, cleaning your fruits and vegetables, and cooking meats well. Wash your hands with soap and water before handling food.  [[Would you like more information about How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?]] [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What are respiratory droplets?]]

questionText: Can COVID-19 be spread through surface-touching?
answerText: Current thinking is that COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person through respiratory droplets. But some studies show that the virus can last on surfaces, so it is possible that someone could get the virus by touching a surface that has the virus on it and then touching their mouth, nose, or eyes.   [[Would you like more information about How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?]] [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What are respiratory droplets?]]

questionText: Will warm weather stop the COVID-19 outbreak?
answerText: We do not know if warm weather will slow the COVID-19 spread. Some viruses, like the common cold or flu, spread better during the cold weather months than in the warm weather months. We are still learning about how weather and temperature affect spread of COVID-19.

questionText: Will high temperatures or heat kill COVID-19?
answerText: Hot water can kill germs, but it has to be very hot - too hot for humans to bear without injuring themselves. Being out in the sun or hot weather, taking long baths, or using hand dryers will not prevent you from getting COVID-19. Also, the virus is still spreading in countries with hot weather.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionText: Is six feet a best practice, or is that a 100% safe zone?
answerText: Staying at least six feet (2 meters) from other people can help reduce the spread. But this does not mean for sure that you will not get the virus.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionText: Will herd immunity be the only means of controlling COVID-19?
answerText: Herd immunity is not the only way to control COVID-19.   Herd immunity is when enough of the population is immune to an infectious disease that the disease will not spread easily from person to person. This could happen either because most people are vaccinated for the disease or because they were sick before and are now immune. For COVID-19, that would mean that enough people would have to recover from the disease and become immune to reduce the person-to-person spread since there is not a vaccine yet.  The other way of controlling the spread of COVID-19 is to practice social distancing and frequent hand-washing. This helps to prevent too many people from getting sick with COVID-19 at once, which could lead to more sick people than hospitals can handle.   [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about Can you be re-infected with COVID-19?]]

questionText: Does hand-washing kill the virus?
answerText: Hand-washing is one of the best ways to keep yourself and your family from getting sick. Washing your hands well can remove all tarces of the virus on your hands. To wash your hands well,  use soap and water for at least 20 seconds.   Make sure to wash your hands:  - After blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing - After using the restroom - Before or after eating or making food - After being in a public place - After touching things that many other people have touched like door handles or tables  If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol. However, hand sanitizers do not get rid of all types of germs, so it is best to wash your hands as soon as you can.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionText: Can you be re-infected with COVID-19?
answerText: Experts are still studying whether you can be re-infected with COVID-19. With other types of coronavirus, experts say that patients are immune to the specific virus for months or even years, but we need more research to tell if this is the case for COVID-19.

questionText: Does washing clothes in the washing machine prevent transmission?
answerText: The virus that causes COVID-19 is very susceptible to soaps. So when you wash clothes, use detergent. The CDC says it is fine to wash an infected person’s clothes with those of someone who is not ill. The CDC advises using your regular laundry detergent and then drying the clothes thoroughly at the warmest temperature recommended on the clothing label.

questionText: How does COVID-19 kill people?
answerText: Most people don't die from COVID-19. But COVID-19 can kill people by causing lung infection (pneumonia) and swelling (inflammation). When the immune system tries to fight off the pneumonia, this can lead to too much inflammation and damage to the lungs. When this happens, not enough oxygen goes to important organs like the liver, kidney, and brain. If the lung damage is too bad and not enough oxygen gets to the rest of the body, this can cause organ failure and death.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: Is it transmittable through anal sex?
answerText: The virus has been detected in stool, so the virus could spread from person to person through anal sex.   [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionText: Is two weeks enough time to be isolated?
answerText: The CDC has a guideline for determining how and when to stop home isolation. To read about it, please click here:  https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html  [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionText: Can I get the virus from breathing infected particles?
answerText: Yes, COVID-19 can spread through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What are respiratory droplets?]]

questionText: Who should get tested for COVID-19?
answerText: Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19. Doctors and state health departments work to decide who should be tested based on their symptoms. Some of the factors that help decide if someone needs testing include their symptoms, how sick they are, if they have other health problems, and if they have contact with other vulnerable groups. Talk to your doctor if you think you need to be tested.  [[Would you like more information about what are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: When should I get tested for COVID-19?
answerText: Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19. Doctors and state health departments work to decide who should be tested based on their symptoms. Some of the factors that help decide if you need testing include your symptoms, how sick you are, if you have other health problems, and if you have contact with other vulnerable groups. Talk to your doctor if you think you need to be tested.  [[Would you like more information about what are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: How can I get tested for COVID-19?
answerText: Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19. Getting tested usually will NOT help you get better treatment because currently there are no approved treatments for COVID-19. most people will not get very sick and can get better at home. Since there are not enough tests for everyone, it is important to make sure that people like health care workers and other high-risk groups can get tested first.  Please call your health care provider or the health department in your town or state to find out if you need to be tested.  [[Would you like more information about what are the symptoms of COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: Is the COVID-19 test anonymous?
answerText: If you test positive for COVID-19, that will be reported to public health authorities. This is so that they can track the outbreak. Based on where you live, they may alert others who also might have been exposed so those people can take action to prevent further spread.  [[Would you like more information about where to get tested for COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about Who should get tested for COVID-19?]]

questionText: What should I do if I think I have COVID-19?
answerText: If you have one of these symptoms, you should call 911 or emergency medical services to seek care right away:  -Trouble breathing -Pain or pressure in the chest that won't go away -Feeling confused -Lips or face that look blue  If this is not an emergency, this symptom checker by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) can help you find out if you could have COVID-19. It can also help you decide what to do next. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/index.html  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I get tested for COVID-19?]]

questionText: Can a person test negative and later test positive for COVID-19?
answerText: In general, a negative or normal result means that the virus that causes COVID-19 was not found in the sample. But sometimes if a person has COVID-19 in the early stages, they could test negative at first, but test positive later on, when there is more virus present. You healthcare provider can help decide if you should be tested again.  [[Would you like more information about Who should get tested for COVID-19?]]

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionText: Are there any natural health products that can treat or prevent COVID-19?
answerText: At this time, there are no natural health products that are known to treat or protect against COVID-19.

questionText: Are antibiotics effective in preventing or treating COVID-19?
answerText: Antibiotics will not work in treating COVID-19. Antibiotics only work against bacteria. COVID-19 is caused by a virus, not bacteria.

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionText: What vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?
answerText: There is currently no vaccine or treatment  for COVID-19, and it might take some time to make one. Right now, scientists are still studying vaccines and some drug treatments to see if they are safe and if they work.  Luckily, most people who get COVID-19 will recover on their own or with treatment with over-the-counter cold or flu medications. Do NOT try to prevent or treat your COVID-19 symptoms using drugs like antibiotics. Talk to your doctor before starting a new medication.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionText: When will a vaccine or treatment become available?
answerText: We do not yet know when a vaccine or treatment will become available. Possible vaccines and some drugs are still being studied.

questionText: Should I take chloroquine?
answerText: Chloroquine Phosphate is a medicine that people usually use to prevent or treat malaria. As of April 2020, it has not been approved to treat COVID-19.   It has been used in experiments to treat a few people with COVID-19 but scientists don't know for sure if it works. Scientists are still testing it.   Please talk to your doctor before taking any medication.   [[Would you like more information about what vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?]]

questionText: Should I take hydroxychloroquinine?
answerText: You should not take hydroxychloroquine unless a doctor prescribed it to you for a specific health issue. Scientists and doctors don't know for sure if hydroxychloroquine works against COVID-19 and they don't know how safe it is. It has some side effects like stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, and headache. It can also have dangerous side effects if you take the wrong dose.

questionText: Can I access to a testing center without a car?
answerText: Testing locations vary from place to place. If you have symptoms of COVID-19 and want to be tested, contact your nearest health department or ask your medical provider.  [[Would you like more information about Who should get tested for COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: How much does it cost to get tested?
answerText: The cost of being tested for coronavirus depends on where you live and if your insurance covers testing. For example, in the United States, government insurance plans and most private plans cover COVID-19 testing for free with an in-network provider. In some other countries, testing is free to all. You should check your own plan for more information.  If you have symptoms of COVID-19 and want to be tested, contact your nearest health department to learn how to be tested, or ask your insurance carrier or health care provider.  [[Would you like more information about Who should get tested for COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: What is the COVID-19 test?
answerText: Right now, the most common test for COVID-19 includes taking a swab through the nose and collecting a sample from the back of the nose and throat. The swab will then be sent to a lab, where it will be tested to see if you have COVID-19 or not. However, labs are trying out new forms of testing.

questionText: What kind of medicine can I take to help ease the symptoms of COVID-19?
answerText: Most people with mild illness will recover on their own, or by using over-the-counter fever or pain relief medications such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) like you would for the flu. If you are taking over-the-counter medications, make sure to follow the directions on the package and pay attention to warnings about taking it with alcohol or other drugs.  Please contact your health care provider before starting any new medications.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk for severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: Would using heated-vapor humidifier help with sanitizing sinuses for COVID-19?
answerText: While using heated-vapor humidifiers may help ease sinus symptoms, this will not sanitize or cure COVID-19.

questionText: Why are ventilators needed?
answerText: A ventilator is a machine that helps you breathe if your body can not do it on its own. COVID-19 can make it hard to breathe. In severe cases, a person with COVID-19 may need help breathing using a ventilator.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: How often should I take my temperature?
answerText: If you think you could have been exposed or infected with COVID-19, take your temperature two times a day (morning and night) every day for 14 days. You should also take your temperature if you start to feel sick or if you think you might have a fever.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]]

questionText: Will a pneumococcal vaccine help protect me against coronavirus
answerText: Vaccines against pneumonia, such as the pneumococcal vaccine, do not protect against COVID-19.

questionText: Do the test results work if you don't have symptoms?
answerText: The COVID-19 test usually does not help most people without symptoms, although your health care provider might decide to test you if you were exposed to an infected person. Sometimes you can test positive if you are infected but don't have symptoms yet. But no test is perfect. You could also get a "false negative" result. This means that you could still have the disease even if the test result is negative (normal).   You should continue to stay at home if possible and follow social distancing guidelines, even if you do not have symptoms.  [[What is social distancing?]] [[What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[What is self-monitoring?]]

questionText: Should I use NSAIDs?
answerText: At this time, there is not scientific evidence to show if NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), like ibuprofen, make COVID-19 symptoms worse. But scientists are still studying this. If you are worried about using NSAIDs, speak to your health care provider to learn more.

questionText: How can I get tested if I am asymptomatic?
answerText: If you do not have symptoms such as fever, cough or shortness of breath, you probably do not need to be tested for COVID-19 at this time. Getting tested usually will NOT help you get better treatment. You should continue to stay at home as much as you can and follow social distancing guidelines, even if you do not feel sick.  Please contact your provider if you begin to havesymptoms of COVID-19 or if you have any changes in your health.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionText: How long is the treatment?
answerText: At this time, there is no  treatment for COVID-19. Most people who get COVID-19 will recover on their own or with treatment with over-the-counter cold or flu medications. People who have more severe illness might need to go to the hospital for care. The length of time to recovery varies from one person to another. Most people take about two weeks to recover from COVID-19. People with severe symptoms or other conditions might take between 3 and 6 weeks to recover.

questionText: How long does it take to get the test results back?
answerText: How long it takes to get results backs depends on which test was used and which laboratory is doing the testing. It can take up to one week to get test results back. You should ask the the provider that did the test how long they think it will take for the test results to come.  While waiting for your results, please stay at home and monitor your symptoms. If your symptoms get worse, please contact your provider.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: How to treat coronavirus naturally?
answerText: If you are at home with mild symptoms, you may be able to relieve symptoms by getting extra rest and sleep, drinking enough liquids to stay hydrated, staying warm, and using a humidifier or taking a hot shower to help a sore throat and cough. If you are thinking about taking any supplement or natural medicine, please talk to your healthcare provider first to make sure there are no negative side effects. Right now, there is no evidence that any supplements or natural medicines can treat COVID-19.

questionText: If I'm high risk, what should I do?
answerText: If you are high risk and there is an outbreak near you, you should: 1. Stay home as much as you can  2. Stock up on supplies like nonperishable foods and medicines  3. Limit travel as much as you can  4. Watch for symptoms and emergency signs    If you must interact with others, you should: 1. Keep at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people  2. Stay away from crowds  3. Stay away from people who are sick  4. Wash your hands often with soap and water  5. Don't touch your face    If you get sick, please call your doctor.   To learn more about how to prepare, click here: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/specific-groups/high-risk-complications.html  [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Is there COVID-19 in my area?]]

questionText: How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?
answerText: First, please remember that surgical masks should only be used by health workers, caretakers, and people who have COVID-19 symptoms like a cough or a fever.  To put on a surgical mask, you should: 1. Wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer BEFORE touching the mask 2. Look at the mask for tears and holes. 3. Find which side is the top side. If the mask has a metal strip or stiff edge, that is the top side. 4. Check that the right side of the mask is facing away from you. The colored side should face away from you. 5. Place the mask to your face. Pinch the metal strip or the stiff edge of the mask so that it molds to the shape of your nose. 6. Pull down the bottom of the mask so it covers your mouth and chin  To take off and dispose of a surgical mask: 1. Remove the elastic loops from behind your ears, while keeping the mask away from your face and clothes. This is to avoid touching potentially contaminated surfaces of the mask 2. Throw the mask away in a closed trash can right after use 3. Wash your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer after touching or throwing away the mask.    [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: Should people avoid products shipped from China?
answerText: Since the virus has spread all over the world, there is no reason to be more concerned about a product from China compared to a product shipped from somewhere else. Most cases of coronavirus spread through close contact with an infected person. It is much less likely to get it from touching a surface like a package. To be very careful, you could wipe down the package, wait for a few days before you open the package, and wash your hands with soap and water after touching the package.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionText: Can I donate blood?
answerText: You can donate blood as long as you are not sick. Donated blood is always needed. If you are well and eligible, please consider donating. The CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) is giving blood centers like the Red Cross advice on how to keep blood donors and staff safe from COVID-19.

questionText: What can I do to reduce my and my family's risk of getting COVID-19?
answerText: You can reduce your risk of getting sick by:  1. Staying at home as much as you can. Only go out when you really need to (for groceries, for example) 2. If you do go out, keep at least 6 foot (2 meter) distance between you and other people. 3. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, coming home and before eating or makng food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands are visibly dirty.  4. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol. 5. Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles).   If you or someone in your family gets sick, stay at home, except when getting medical care, until your doctor says you no longer have to stay home. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?]]

questionText: What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?
answerText: Most people who get COVID-19 will be able to recover at home. If possible, have the sick household member use a separate room and bathroom. Try to have the sick family member stay away from other people as much as they can. Clean and sanitize your hands and home regularly.  Don't share personal items like utensils, foods, and drinks.  The sick person should stay at home except to get medical care. Please contact a health care provider right away if they have one of these severe symptoms: -Trouble breathing  -Shortness of breath  -Chest pain or pressure that won't go away -Feeling very tired or unable to wake up from sleeping -Lips or face look blue  Please keep in mind that this is not the full list. If someone in your house has one of these severe symptoms or something that worries you, please contact your medical provider.

questionText: What can I do if schools, daycares, and universities closed down?
answerText: It is a challenging time with schools, daycares and unversities being closed. Please talk to the schools and facilities about their emergency operation plans.

questionText: What should I do if there is an outbreak in my community?
answerText: If there is an outbreak in your community, you should:  1. Stay calm! 2. Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people 3. Stay informed about the local COVID-19 situation through your local health department 4. Wash your hands 5. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissue 6. Clean surfaces that people touch a lot  Please stay home if you are sick, and limit contact with others as much as you can.  Notify your workplace as soon as possible if your regular work schedule will need to change. Ask to work from home or take leave if your or someone in your home gets sick with COVID-19 symptoms or if your child's school is dismissed.   If you live alone and have a chronic health problem, please reach out to friends, family, loved ones, and healthcare providers. Also ask them to check in on you. Stay in touch with loved ones by phone or email. This can be a lonely and isolating time, so it is important to practice self-care as well as reach out to others.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionText: Can I go outside for a walk during shutdown?
answerText: In most places, you can still go for a walk during a shelter in place order as long as you are abiding by your local state or county's rules. In general, here are a few tips:  -Stay at least 6 feet away from other people -Limit how long you will be outside, especially if there is a COVID-19 outbreak near you -Do not go to places where there are lots of people or crowds  This may not be allowed if you are in a location with strict quarantine measures. If you are or might be infected with COVID-19, you should not go for a walk outside, and should be self-isolating or in quarantine.   [[Would you like more information about What is social-distancing?]]

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionText: Can COVID-19 be transmitted through food?
answerText: There is currently no evidence to suggest that food is a likely way of spreading COVID-19. Food safety experts are closely watching the spread of COVID-19.

questionText: Any advice about how to minimize risk during grocery shopping trips or getting takeout.
answerText: Like other viruses, it is possible that the virus that causes COVID-19 can stay on surfaces and objects. Here are some tips to reduce risk while grocery shopping:   1. Shop when stores are less busy 2. Disinfect the shopping cart at the grocery store  3. Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from others while shopping 4. Avoid touching your face while shopping  5. While paying, avoid hand-to-hand cash transfers. Wipe down debit or credit cards after using them. 5. Wash your hands as soon as you come home with soap and water  You can also see if delivery services are available in you area. In some areas, you may be able to buy directly from local farmers and producers.  [[Would you like more information about Are there services available to help older adults get groceries?]]

sourceName: JHU Public Health Wirecutter NY Times
questionText: Also, what to do if you have no access to sanitizing wipes
answerText: If you don't have access to hand sanitizer, soap and water are always the best option.  Make sure any hand santizer you have has at least 60% alcohol, as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Any hand sanitizer that has less than 60% alcohol will not be effective at killing the virus.

questionText: How long should we self-quarantine for?
answerText: Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days.   Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days. Remember, every time you could have been exposed to the virus means you should restart your 14 day clock for quarantine.  [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?]]

questionText: How can I protect myself and others?
answerText: Although the risk of infection on an airplane is low, try to avoid contact with sick passengers, avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth with unwashed hands, and wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. You should also wear a cloth face covering while at the airport and on the plane.

questionText: Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?
answerText: Washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is the best way to protect yourself and your family from getting sick! Wash your hands regularly, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, going to the restroom, and before eating or preparing food. If you do not have soap and water, use an alcohol based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionText: What types of cleaning products should I use to protect against COVID-19?
answerText: For disinfecting purposes, most common EPA registered household disinfectants will work. Please click here for link. It is important to clean frequently touched surfaces like tables, doorknobs, light switches, countertops, handles, desks, phones, keyboards, toilets, faucets, and sinks. If your surfaces are dirty, clean them using detergent or soap and water prior to disinfection.

questionText: Should I stay home and even avoid going to the supermarket and drugstore?
answerText: If you believe you have been exposed to COVID-19, or if you are at high risk of symptoms, you should not go to the grocery store. Depending on where you traveled to, your local or national government may recommend that you stay quarantine for a period after recent travel.

questionText: How long does the virus stay in paper money and coins?
answerText: We don't know for sure how long the virus can last on coins and paper money. In laboratory studies, scientists found that it could last up to 4 hours on copper (similar to coins) and up to 24 hours on cardboard (similar to paper). It is unclear how long the virus can last on surfaces in the real world. It is best to wash your hands well after handling money.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionText: Does the virus stay on clothing?
answerText: Researchers found that the virus can stay on some surfaces for up to 72 hours, but the study didn’t include fabric. It is best to have a pair of outside clothes to wear on errands and remove them when you come home. Wash your clothes frequently.   [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionText: How do I take care of those infected with COVID-19?
answerText: If you are caring for someone with COVID-19 at home, prevent the spread of germs, treat symptoms, and monitor for emergency signs.   1. Prevent the spread. If possible, have the sick household member use a separate room and bathroom. Have the sick person stay away from other people and pets as much as they can.  Don't share personal items like towels, dishes, and food. If the person needs to be around other people, they should wear a facemask. If they cannot wear a facemask, others should wear one while in the same room. The sick person should stay at home except to get medical care.   To protect yourself, avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth. Disinfect all surfaces that are touched often, like tabletops and doorknobs, using cleaning sprays or wipes. If laundry is soiled, wear disposable gloves and keep laundry away from your body while washing. Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol.    2. Treat symptoms. Most people  with COVID-19 can get better with rest and drinking plenty of fluids. Symptoms usually last a few days and get better after a week. Keep track of symptoms, especially fevers.   3. Monitor for emergency signs. Contact a health care provider right away if they have one of these severe symptoms: -Trouble breathing  -Shortness of breath  -Chest pain or pressure that won't go away -Feeling very tired or unable to wake up from sleeping -Lips or face look blue  If someone in your house has one of these severe symptoms or something that worries you, please contact your medical provider. In the case of an emergency, call 911 and tell the dispatcher that the person has or might have COVID-19.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: Will ingesting soap bubbles kill COVID-19 in my lungs?
answerText: No, ingesting soap will not kill COVID-19 in your lungs. Trying to ingest or inhale soap could actually cause more damage to your lungs.

questionText: How do I sew a face mask?
answerText: The CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) recommends using cloth face coverings or masks in public settings to slow the spread of the virus. Learn how to make homemade cloth face coverings here: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/diy-cloth-face-coverings.html  [[Would you like more information about How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?]]

questionText: What are other options to wash my hands if I don't have soap and water?
answerText: If soap and water are unavailable, using a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol can help you avoid getting sick and spreading germs to others.

questionText: Is staying at home mandatory?
answerText: Whether staying at home is mandatory depends on where you are located. You should check with your local, state, territorial, or tribal health department to find out what the recommendations are for your area.

questionText: Does a mask actually help if I am sick or not?
answerText: The virus can spread between people even if they do not have symptoms or feel ill. Because of this, the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) recommends wearing cloth face masks in public. This can help to slow the spread of the virus so that people who are sick but do not realize it do not spread the virus to healthy people.  [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I sew a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?]]

questionText: Is it safe for seniors to go out for a walk or inside shopping malls which are quite isolated these days
answerText: The CDC recommends that older adults (age 65 and older) and others who are at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19 should stay home and practice social and physical distancing.

questionText: Can I move in with family if we have all been symptom free for 14 days?
answerText: Every situation is different. You should talk to your health provider to decide if it is safe for you to move in with you family. Here are a few questions to talk about:   1. Is your current home unsafe or unfit to live in?  2. Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you’re going?  3. Will you be in close contact with others while you travel?  4. Are you or the people you will be living with with more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  5. Will you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic health problem?  6. Is everyone you are moving in with following the social distancing or self-isolation guidelines?  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionText: Can you see friends if you stick to the social distancing guidelines?
answerText: You should follow the recommended guidelines from authorities where you live. If you are not able to see friends in person, you should look for social support in other ways. For example, talking on the phone, having video calls, or sending letters to friends.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionText: I worry about my mental health during quarantine, what can I do to help it?
answerText: If you are worried about your mental health during this time, you are not alone. If you are concerned that you may be at risk of harming yourself or someone else you know, please call 911 or the equivalent emergency services in your country.   Here are some ways to cope with stress that some people find helpful: 1. Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories. 2. Take breaks from social media. 3. Take care of your body by trying to eat healthy meals, exercising at home, and avoiding alcohol and drugs. 4. Make time to unwind and do activities you enjoy. 5. Spend time talking to others, while practicing social distancing. If you have a phone or Internet access, call someone you trust and talk to them about how you are feeling.  If you are feeling overwhelmed by sadness, depression, or anxiety, please seek help from a trusted provider. If you have a mental health condition please continue your treatment. If you want or plan to harm yourself or others, please call an emergency number or hotline.

questionText: Should I go to the ER or my physician directly if I'm infected?
answerText: If you believe you have COVID-19, please contact your health provider. Your healthcare provider will help you determine if you should be tested and if your symptoms are mild enough to be safe at home. Most people with mild symptoms of COVID-19 can get better at home. If this is not an emergency, this symptom checker by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) can help you find out if you could have COVID-19. It can also help you decide what to do next. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/index.html  If you have one of these symptoms, you should call 911 or emergency medical services to seek care right away and tell the dispatcher that you think you have COVID-19:  -Trouble breathing -Pain or pressure in the chest that won't go away -Feeling confused -Lips or face that look blue   [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms? ]]

questionText: What are other options to sanitize surfaces if I don't have soap and water?
answerText: If you do not have soap and water, you can use:  -Household disinfectant. Please be sure to follow instructions on the product's label.  -Alcohol solutions that contain at least 70% alcohol -Diluted bleach solution, depending on the surface you want to clean. Check the label to make sure you can use the solution for disinfecting and that it is not expired. Follow the instructions on the label. Leave the solution on the surface for at least 1 minute. Do NOT mix bleach with ammonia or any other cleaner.  [[Would you like more information about How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?]]

sourceName: JHU Public Health from info sheet
questionText: How do I quarantine myself if I live with my family or roommates?
answerText: If you or someone you live with is infected, or at high risk of being infected, you should stay in another room as much as you can and use a separate bedroom and bathroom if possible.  Other ways of protecting yourself include:  -Avoid sharing household items like dishes, cups, towels, and bedding -Wash your hands regularly or use hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol -Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot -Wash laundry frequently and thoroughly -If you have pets, the infected person should not care for them -Don't have visitors in your home -The person who is sick should wear a mask if possible

questionText: Should someone continue to self-isolate even if they are feeling better?
answerText: If you have symptoms of coronavirus, you'll need to self-isolate for 7 days. After 7 days, you no longer need to self-isolate if you do not have a high temperature. If you still have a temperature, keep self-isolating until your temperature is back to normal. You do not need to self-isolate if your only symptom after 7 days is a cough, because a cough can last for several weeks after the infection is gone.  If you live with someone with symptoms of COVID-19, you should self-isolate for 14 days starting the day their symptoms started. If more than one person at home has symptoms, self-isolate for 14 days starting the day the first person's symptoms started. If you get symptoms, self-isolate for 7 days starting when your symptoms began, even if this is longer than the original 14 days. If you do not get symptoms, you can stop self-isolating after 14 days.

questionText: If I am still quarantined, can I go out?
answerText: If you are quaranting, it is important to not leave your home for any reason and do not have any visitors in your home. If you need food or medicine, order them by phone or online, or ask someone else to drop them off at your home. You can use your garden, if you have one, as a long as its not a space you share with anyone else. Only exercise at home during your quarantine period.

questionText: Does gargling salt water work?
answerText: No, there is no evidence that gargling salt water prevents or kill COVID-19.

questionText: Does drinking hot water kill COVID-19?
answerText: Drinking hot water will not protect you from getting COVID-19. That's becuase water needs to be very hot to kill the virus - too hot for people to safely drink. You should not drink boiling water as it can cause severe burns in your mouth and throat.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionText: Is it safe to use ride-sharing services (e.g. Lyft, Uber)?
answerText: If possible, avoid using any kind of public transportation, ridesharing, or taxis. If you have to use these options, make sure to be safe and cautious, and apply whatever social distancing measures are possible in the vehicle. In some areas, wearing a face mask has become mandatory, so make sure you are aware of what the current recommended and mandatory practices are in your area.

questionText: How do I take my temperature?
answerText: You can take your body temperature a few different ways. The most common ones are the mouth, the ear, the armpit, and the rectum. The best way for adults is orally, which uses a thermometer in your mouth. This is the most accurate way.  To take your temperature using a digital thermometer:  1. Place the tip of the thermometer in your mouth, under the tongue and close to the middle.  2. Keep your lips closed and hold the thermometer in place with your tongue and fingers. Don't bite it.  3. Based on the thermometer type, you will hear a beep in about 30 seconds or some other signal. You can take the thermometer out.  4. Take the thermometer out and read the temperature.  In most adults, a fever is an oral temperature above 100.4°F (38°C).   [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]]

questionText: Can you use any soap to wash your hands?
answerText: You can use bar soap or liquid soap to wash your hands. Both work just as well to get rid of germs as long as you wash your hands the right way. Studies have not found that antibacterials soaps work any better than plain soap.  [[Would you like more information about Does hand-washing kill the virus?]] [[Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?]]

questionText: Can I move during a pandemic?
answerText: You should check with your moving company and local officials to see if there are travel or group restrictions that would prevent you from moving.  While you may be allowed to move during COVID-19, please consider the following things to determine whether it is in your best interest:  - Is your current home unsafe or uninhabitable?  - Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you’re going?  - Will you be in close contact with others during your trip?  - Are you or the people you are moving with more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  - Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If moving is essential, these same questions can help you plan your relocation to be as safe as possible. If you plan to move in with someone, consider talking to your healthcare provider to see if its safe for you to move at this time.

questionText: What are COVID-19 symptoms?
answerText: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, feeling tired, and dry cough. Some patients may also have aches and pains, stuffy nose, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea.  Most people have mild symptoms that get worse slowly. Most people start to feel sick between 1 and 14 days after being exposed to COVID-19.Some people get infected but don't feel sick at all.   Older people (those who are 65 or older) and people with health problems like diabetes, high blood pressure, or heart problems are more likely to get very sick from COVID-19.   If you or someone you know has one of these problems, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away  -Starting to feel confused  -Can't wake up from sleeping  -Lips or face look blue   If someone has one of these severe symptoms, they need care right away.
