[[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for severe illness?]]

questionText: How likely am I to catch COVID-19?
answerText: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, feeling tired, and dry cough. Some patients may also have aches and pains, stuffy nose, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea.  Most people have mild symptoms that get worse slowly. Most people start to feel sick between 1 and 14 days after being exposed to COVID-19.Some people get infected but don't feel sick at all.   Older people (those who are 65 or older) and people with health problems like diabetes, high blood pressure, or heart problems are more likely to get very sick from COVID-19.   If you or someone you know has one of these problems, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away  -Starting to feel confused  -Can't wake up from sleeping  -Lips or face look blue   If someone has one of these severe symptoms, they need care right away.   [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for severe illness?]]

sourceName: JHU Public Health National foundation for infectious disease
questionText: Is COVID-19 the same as the flu?
answerText: The symptoms of COVID-19 and flu are very similar. Both can cause fever, cough, and shortness of breath. To know for sure if you have COVID-19, you will need to get tested.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I get tested for COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about Who should get tested for COVID-19?}]

questionText: What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID?
answerText: If you think you had contact with someone with COVID-19, you should quarantine yourself for at least 14 days (or two weeks) so that you don't spread the disease. Most people who get sick from COVID-19 get symptoms 1 to 14 days after being exposed. If you have any symptoms related to COVID-19, you should self-isolate and talk to your health care provider.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about What are Covid-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionText: Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?
answerText: People are more likely to get a severe case of COVID-19 if they are:  -Older than 65 years old -Living in a nursing home or long term care facility -Pregnant -In a prison or jail  People are also more likely to get a severe case if they have a health problem such as:  -Lung disease -Asthma -Diabetes -Sickle cell disease -Liver cirrhosis (liver scarring) -Recent chemotherapy -A weaker immune system   [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?]]

questionText: Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?
answerText: You could be at higher risk of catching COVID-19 if many people have gotten COVID-19 near where you live. You could also have a higher risk if you visit places where many people are getting sick with COVID-19.  Right now, in most places, the risk of catching COVID-19 is still low. But this is changing quickly in many cities and areas around the world.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: Where do I go if I have mild symptoms?
answerText: If you only have mild symptoms, it is safest to stay home. Most people with mild symptoms from COVID-19 are able to recover at home without medical care.  To keep the virus from spreading, you should: -Avoid public areas -Stay home, except to get medical care -If you think you need to go to the clinic or hospital, call before you go.    If you get one of these severe symptoms, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away -Starting to feel confused -Lips or face look blue

questionText: How painful would it be if I got the virus?
answerText: How painful the symptoms are depend on the how badly you get sick. Some people get very sick and others don't get very sick at all. You might have fever, tiredness, dry cough. aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat or diarrhea.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: Can you die from getting COVID-19?
answerText: Most people (80%, or 8 out of 10) who get COVID-19 get better without needing special treatment. But there is a small percent of people who get more severe disease and could die or need to go to the hospital.   [[Would you like more information about Why are the death rates so different across countries?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionText: Can my child get sick from COVID-19?
answerText: From what doctors know now, children are not at a higher risk of Covid-19 than adults. Children can become sick with it, but not as often as adults. Most children who have gotten sick with COVID-19 have had mild symptoms, like fever, runny nose, and cough. Some have also had vomiting and diarrhea.  We are still learning if children with some underlying medical conditions may have a higher risk.  [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: How can I protect my child from COVID-19?
answerText: You can protect your child by having them wash hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds and avoid people who are sick. They should also stay away from people outside your home. This means you should avoid playdates, playing on public playgrounds, or being physically close to friends.  You should also clean and disinfect surfaces that you touch a lot in household common areas like tables, chairs, and doorknobs. Wash clothes and plush toys frequently.  [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionText: Are symptoms of COVID-19 different in children?
answerText: Children and adults have the same COVID19 symptoms, although children might not get as sick as adults. Children might get a fever, runny nose, or cough. Some children have had vomiting or diarrhea. We are still learning about how COVID-19 affects children.  [[Would you like more information about how can i protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]]

questionText: Should children wear masks?
answerText: Children under the age of 2 years should not wear any type of masks. Because babies' airways are smaller, breathing through a mask is even harder on them and they are more likely to suffocate if they use a mask. Older infants or young toddlers are not likely to keep the mask on and will likely try to remove it. This will mean they are touching their face more and could infect themselves with the virus. It is safest to keep children at home and follow social distancing.  [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[What is social distancing?]]

questionText: Can I take my child to the playground?
answerText: Right now, experts recommend staying away from the playground because there are many germs at the playground. Children can still play outside, but they should not be in large groups (more than 10 people). They should wash their hands with soap and water for at least twenty seconds.   [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]]

questionText: How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?
answerText: It is important to talk with your child about what is going on. This is a hard time and children will have questions. Stay calm, talk to them about the outbreak, and tell them what you are doing as a family to stay safe.

questionText: Why are schools closing down because of COVID-19?
answerText: Closing schools helps to slow the spread COVID-19. The purpose of closing schools is to prevent students from passing the virus to each other, and then having students pass it to their families. Please keep up with local news media sources, as they will share news about school closures. If schools are closed, your child should stay home. They should avoid groups of people and avoid visiting friends or public places.  [[Would you like more information about How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect my child from COVID-19?]]

questionText: Are children immune to COVID-19?
answerText: Right now, most experts think that children can get the virus at the same rates as adults. But children usually don't get as sick as adults. If a child gets COVID-19, their symptoms are going to be similar to the symptoms adults get. These include fever, runny nose, and cough. Vomiting and diarrhea are also possible.   [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionText: Am I at greater risk of adverse COVID-19 outcomes if I am pregnant?
answerText: Doctors don't yet know for sure if pregnant women have a higher risk of having severe symptoms or long-term effects if they get COVID-19. But it is always important for pregnant women to protect themselves from getting sick. Proper hygiene such as washing hands can help reduce the risk of getting infected of spreading the virus to others.  If you are pregnant and concerned about COVID-19, talk to your doctor.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionText: What do I do if I've tested positive for COVID-19 and am about to deliver?
answerText: If you've have COVID-19 and are pregnant, tell the obstetric unit and hospital before you go there. This is so that they can prepare to keep you and your baby as safe as they can.  [[Would you like more information about What precautions I shoudl take if I am going to the hospital for delivery?]]

questionText: What precautions should I take if I am going to the hospital for delivery?
answerText: If you are pregnant, here are some steps you can take to stay healthy:  1.        Wash your hands. You’ve heard this advice over and over. But that’s because it works! Keeping hands clean can stop the virus in its tracks. 2.        Practice “social distancing.” Stay away from other people and large groups. If you need to be around others, try to keep 6 feet (2 meters) away. 3.        Get the flu shot. It won’t protect you against COVID-19. But it will lower your risk of getting the flu since the flu can also cause problems for pregnant moms. 4.        Go virtual. Try to have virtual (online) or phone visits with your doctor whenever you can. Spending less time in the waiting room and office can help you stay healthy. However, you might still need an in-person visit for some things like ultrasounds or blood work. 5.        Call your doctor if you’re coughing. If you have symptoms like cough, fever, or shortness of breath, call or email your doctor. They will decide if you should be tested for COVID-19 and tell you what to do next.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]  [[Would you like more information about What precautions should I take if I am going to the hospital for delivery?]]

questionText: Can my pet (dog, cat, other animal) get COVID-19?
answerText: Right now, we don't know of any clear cases of the virus passing from people to their pets. There was a tiger in a zoo in New York City that seems to have gotten COVID-19 from its caretakers. To be safe, wash your hands before and after touching animals.   Until we know more, if you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and have a pet or other animal, you should:  1. Avoid close contact with them. Do not snuggle or kiss them, let them lick you, sit on your lap, or sleep in your bed. 2. Avoid coughing and sneezing on your animals. Cover your coughs and sneezes. 3. Have another member of your household care for your animals, if you can. 4. If it's not possible to have someone else care for your animal, always wash your hands before touching or feeding them. 5. Limit your animal's contact with other people and animals. Tthis may mean keeping them indoors.  We might learn more about human to animal spread in the future. Talk to your pet's doctor if you are worried about your pet's health.

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from animals when travelling to other countries?
answerText: Right now, COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person. But experts agree that the virus likely came from bats and may have passed through another type of animal in China before spreading to people. If you are going to travel, check the latest health notices for up-to-date advice before you leave. Avoid contact with animals, including wild meat and live animal markets.  Animal importers, rescues, and adoptive families should limit or postpone importing animals from affected areas. If animals are imported from an affected area, monitor them closely for illness. Call a veterinarian if they get sick and call before bringing them to the office so that they can prepare.  [[Would you like more information about Should I avoid traveling?]]

questionText: Can coronavirus live on pet fur (hair)
answerText: As of April 7, 2020 there is no evidence that coronavirus can be spread to people from the skin or fur of pets.

questionText: Can COVID-19 in cats be treated?
answerText: As of April 2020, there is no evidence that pets (such as cats or dogs) can spread COVID-19. If you have questions about the health of your pet you should contact your veterinarian.

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionText: Should I avoid traveling?
answerText: If you are thinking about traveling, check the latest travel health notices for the most up-to-date travel advice before you go. It is important to limit travel as much as possible.   If you think you need to travel, please go through these questions:   1. Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you're going?  If it is, you may be more likely to get infected if you travel there than if you stay at home.   2. Will you or the people who you are traveling with be in close contact with others during your trip?  Your risk increases in crowded settings, especially closed-in settings that do not have good circulation. This includes conferences, concerts, etc.   3. Are you or your travel companion more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  People at higher risk for severe disease are older adults and people of any age with serious chronic medical conditions (e.g. heart disease, lung disease, diabetes). If you are at higher risk, avoid all cruise travel and non-essential air travel.   4. Do you have a plan for taking time off from work or school, in case you are told to stay home for 14 days for self-monitoring or if you get sick with COVID-19?  You may be asked to take time off, and be unable to go to work or school until you are considered non-infectious.   5. Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If you get sick with COVID-19 while you travel, your family, friends, loved ones may be at risk of getting sick. People who are older and who have health problems are more likely to get very sick.  6. Is COVID-19 spreading where I live when I return from travel?  Even if you don't feel sick right now, you could pass on COVID-19 to others during travel without knowing it. This is very important if you'll be in contact with people who are older adults or have a severe chronic health problem. These people are at higher risk of getting very sick.   It is important to go through these questions to decide if it makes sense to travel.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about Is there Covid in my area?]]

questionText: What should I do if I just returned from a trip?
answerText: If you do not have any symptoms, you will be asked to:  1. Self-quarantine for 14 days after you get home.  2. Do not have any visitors, especially older adults, or those with health problems who are higher risk of severe illness. 3. Monitor your health for fever, cough, or trouble breathing. 4. Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use an alcohol based hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol. 5. Cover your mouth and nose with your arm or a tissue when coughing or sneezing. Throw away the tissue right after and wash your hands.   If you start to have symptoms like a cough or fever within the 14 days:  1. Continue to self-isolate from others.  2. Call a healthcare professional or a public health authority and tell them your symptoms and travel history. Follow their instructions.  3.  If your symptoms are severe - such as pain or pressure in the chest that won't go away, trouble breathing, feeling confused or unable to arouse, or lips or face that look blue, seek medical care right away. Please contact your medical provider if you have questions about your health and safety.   [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionText: Can i go to the funeral of someone who died of COVID-19?
answerText: Right now, we don't know of any higher risk due to being in the same room at a funeral or visitation service with the body of someone who has died of COVID-19 as long as you stay 6 feet (2 meters) away. That being said, for now we must all avoid large gatherings and stay at home as much as we can to reduce the spread of COVID-19.

questionText: Am I at risk if I touch someone who has died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
answerText: Generally, do not touch the body of someone who has died of COVID-19. We are still learning how COVID-19 spreads and if a deceased body can transmit the virus. One could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it, and then touching their face (like their mouth, nose, or eyes).   Try to avoid kissing washing, and shrouding the body. If washing and shrouding the body are important in your culture or religion, work with your community cultural and religious leaders as well as funeral home staff to try to reduce exposure as much as possible. People who conduct these activities should wear disposable gloves. If fluid splashing is expected, more personal protective equipment may be needed, such as disposable gowns, goggles, and face masks.

questionText: What should I do if my family member dies of COVID-19 while overseas?
answerText: If a U.S. citizen dies outside the United States, that person's next of kin or legal representative should notify the US Consular officials at the Department of State. These people are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and provide assistance to US citizens for overseas emergencies.   If the family member, domestic partner, next of kin, or legal representative is in a different country than the deceased person, they should call the Department of State's Office of Overseas Citizens Services in Washington DC, from 8a-5p ET, Mon-Fri, at 888-407-4747 (toll-free) or 202-501-444. For emergency assistance after working hours or on weekends/holidays, call the Department of State switchboard at 202-647-4000 and ask to speak with the Overseas Citizens Services duty officer.   In addition to these steps above, the in-country of closest US embassy can also provide assistance.

questionText: Is it safe to travel in domestic flight with precautions
answerText: Cases of COVID-19 have been reported in all states in the U.S. and some areas have had community spread of the disease. Crowded travel settings, like airports, may increase chances of getting COVID-19 if there are other travelers with COVID-19. Please note that the CDC urges residents of New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut not to travel domestically for 14 days effective immediately. To learn more, please visit: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-in-the-us.html  [[Would you like more information about Should I avoid traveling?]]

questionText: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups because of COVID-19?
answerText: There has been a rise in stigma and hate crimes against Chinese and other Asian Americans, as well as people who were in quarantine. This is due to lack of knowledge around how COVID-19 spreads, a need to blame someone, fears about disease and death, as well as gossip that spreads rumors and myths.  Stigma hurts everyone as it creates more fear and anger towards ordinary people, instead of the disease that is causing the problem, or towards systems that are not supporting people in accessing screening and treatment. Sharing facts about how COVID-19 actually spreads can help stop stigma.

questionText: What is the COVID-19 situation in the U.S?
answerText: All 50 states in the U.S., as well as D.C., Puerto Rico, Guam, and the U.S. Virgin Islands have reported presumptive positive cases of COVID-19.

questionText: Has anyone gotten infected in the United States?
answerText: Yes, all states have reported COVID-19 infections. U.S. case counts are updated regularly Mondays through Fridays. Please click here to see current U.S. case count: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/cases-in-us.html

questionText: What are some safe ways to shop for groceries right now?
answerText: Like other viruses, it is possible that the virus that causes COVID-19 can stay on surfaces and objects. Here are some tips to reduce risk while grocery shopping:   1. Shop when stores are less busy 2. Disinfect the shopping cart at the grocery store  3. Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from others while shopping 4. Avoid touching your face while shopping  5. While paying, avoid hand-to-hand cash transfers. Wipe down debit or credit cards after using them. 5. Wash your hands as soon as you come home with soap and water  You can also see if delivery services are available in you area. In some areas, you may be able to buy directly from local farmers and producers.  [[Would you like more information about Are there services available to help older adults get groceries?]]

questionText: Should I wash and prepare foods differently once I get them home?
answerText: Right now there is no evidence that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can live on surfaces for up to 72 hours, if you are worried you can disinfect food packaging after bringing it home from the store. You should also follow the usual food safety steps like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionText: Are there particular foods I should avoid purchasing, like foods imported from certain countries?
answerText: There is no evidence that COVID-19 can spread through imported foods.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionText: What food should I eat to help boost my immune system?
answerText: Five core micronutrients—vitamin B6, vitamin C, vitamin E, magnesium, and zinc—play roles in maintaining immune function. The best way to get vitamins and minerals is from a well-rounded diet, with plenty of fruits and vegetables (fresh or frozen are fine), legumes, whole grains, and lean sources of protein, along with healthy fats, such as nuts and olive oil.

questionText: Should I eat at restaurants right now?
answerText: Limiting social gatherings is recommended, so it is safest to avoid dining at restaurants and bars. Some restaurants may offer pick-up or delivery options.   [[Would you like more information about what is social distancing?]]

questionText: Should I order delivery or do take-out right now?
answerText: Using drive-thru, pickups, or delivery options to avoid eating and drinking in restaurants, bars, and food courts is fine.

questionText: What are some tips for stocking my pantry on a budget?
answerText: Here are six practical ways to stretch your dollars at the grocery store.  Make Your Menu: Time permitting, write out a basic meal plan for the week and the groceries you’ll need for it.  Respect the Freezer : frozen fruits and vegetables are a cost-effective source of nutrition.  Play the Sale: Look for discounts, coupons, and sales, especially on store brands, which usually cost less.  Go Big: Buy in bulk when you can (e.g., purchase a whole chicken instead of just chicken breasts). Freeze what you don’t immediately need.  Go Home: If you have time, prepare food yourself instead of buying prepared or frozen meals. Thirty minutes will give you enough time to bring together simple, tasty meals.  Read the Fine Print: Compare unit prices (dollars per pound or per ounce) listed on price tags to find the cheapest brand.  Hold the Steak: Because meat can be a relatively expensive source of protein, look to supplement it with plant-based sources of protein like beans, quinoa, and whole-wheat pasta.  Shop the Season: Off-season produce is almost always more expensive and of inferior quality.

questionText: Are we at risk of food shortages or price spikes?
answerText: It is hard to tell right now how COVID-19 will affect food supply and prices.  [[Would you like more information about What are some tips for stocking my pantry on a budget?]]

questionText: Can COVID-19 live in your refrigerator?
answerText: It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object, like a piece of food or a packaging container, that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes. This is not the main way the virus spreads. There is low risk of spreading coronavirus from food products or packaging.  Currently, there is no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food. Before preparing or eating food it is important to always wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds for general food safety.

questionText: Are we going to have trouble buying milk?
answerText: Currently, there is not a known global food shortage. However, it could be harder to get some foods in your area.

questionText: What should I eat or drink to prevent COVID-19?
answerText: There is nothing you can eat or drink to prevent COVID-19. The best thing you can do is to eat a balanced, healthy diet high in fruits and vegetables. There is no “quick fix” for boosting your immune system, but nutrition is important to staying healthy.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionText: Can drinking alcohol help COVID-19?
answerText: Consuming alcohol will not destroy the virus in your mouth or throat. Drinking alcohol could increase your health risks.   You may use alcohol (at a concentration of at least 60%) to clean your skin.   [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionText: How long should I stock up on food for?
answerText: Experts recommend having enough food to last for two weeks.

questionText: Does eating oranges daily help to fight the virus?
answerText: There is no evidence that eating specific foods can prevent you from getting sick. It is important to maintain a balanced and healthy diet high in fruits and vegetables.   [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionText: Can I go grocery shopping if I have just returned from vacation?
answerText: If you think you have been exposed to COVID-19, or if you have symptoms, do not go to the grocery store. Depending on where you traveled to, your local or national government may recommend that you quarantine after recent travel.   [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionText: Can COVID-19 affect chicken?
answerText: Right now, most experts don't think that COVID-19 spreads easily from eating certain foods. But you should always wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds before eating or preparing food.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionText: Can stores open early for the elderly and immunocompromised?
answerText: Some stores may be offering limited hours to seniors, essential workers, or other populations. You should contact your local stores to see if they are providing these services.

questionText: Are there services available to help older adults get groceries?
answerText: There may be services such as grocery delivery available in your area. Some stores may also be offering limited hours to seniors or other high-risk populations. You should contact your local stores to see if they are providing these services.

questionText: How can I help make sure people who are vulnerable get access to food?
answerText: Consider buying only what you need at the grocery store so that others in the community can access supplies they need. If you do have financial resources to contribute to the COVID-19 response, consider donating to food bank networks.

questionText: What is a biological medical product or a biologic?
answerText: Biologics come from a variety of natural sources - human, animal, or microorganism - and may be produced by biotechnology methods and other cutting-edge technologies. Examples include vaccines, blood, and other things made from human cells. Biologics can be made of sugars, proteins, and/or nucleic acids, or may be living things.

questionText: Will COVID-19 decrease a country's blood supplies?
answerText: Blood supplies may be lower than usual due to fewer people donating blood during the pandemic.

questionText: What is a state of emergency? Does it indicate the severity of a situation?
answerText: A state of emergency declaration is simply a way to free up resources. It is a temporary order that allows the governor to assist communities in need better and faster by making resources immediately available. It also makes it easier for the state to seek federal assistance during and after a natural disaster, pandemic and more.

questionText: Is it safe to go to the dentist — or any other routine healthcare provider — in the near future?
answerText: You should speak with your healthcare provider to determine if your visit is urgent at this time or if it can be moved to a later date. Routine visits should be moved to a later date and any dental procedures and surgeries that are not an emergency should be avoided, if possible and advised by your healthcare provider. In an emergency, call your country's emergency number.

questionText: How can I help others?
answerText: The best way to help others is to avoid crowds of people, stay home as much as possible, anad continue practicing good hand hygiene. You will be helping everyone. If you are able to, you can also donate to local food banks and shelters to support others in more vulnerable situations.

questionText: Can SARS-CoV-2 be transmitted by blood transfusion?
answerText: In general, respiratory viruses like the COVID-19 virus are not known to be transmitted by blood transfusion, and there have been no reported cases of transfusion-transmitted coronavirus.

questionText: Can disinfectant sprays or wipes be used on my skin to prevent the spread of COVID-19?
answerText: Always follow the instructions on household cleaners and read all warning labels on cleanign products. Do not use disinfect sprays or wipes on your skin because it may cause skin and eye irritation.  Disinfectant sprays or wipes are not intended for use on humans or animals and should not be consumed.  Disinfectant sprays or wipes are intended for use on hard, non porous surfaces.

questionText: Do N95 respirators provide protection from coronavirus?
answerText: N95 respirators and other personal protective equipment (PPE) such as gloves and surgical gowns are made to create a barrier from disease. However, there is not a 100% guarantee that it will protect against the virus.

questionText: Do expired N95 respirators still offer protection?
answerText: N95 masks really don't expire in terms of their functionality. However, most masks are designed to be used only once and only reach their true effectiveness if they have been tested for their fit. Additionally, over time, the elastic bands that attach the mask to the user's face can become looser and the mask may not provide an ideal fit.

questionText: Can 3D printing be used to make PPE?
answerText: It is possible to use 3D printing to make PPE, but these do not provide the same safety as government approved PPE.

questionText: What are delivery services doing to keep your packages safe?
answerText: Every delivery service has its own procedure and protocols to try and keep packages safe. If you have concerns or want to learn more about what a delivery service is doing, you should contact the delivery service directly to find out what they are doing.

questionText: Can COVID-19 virus can be transmitted in areas with hot and humid climates?
answerText: From the information so far, the COVID-19 virus can happen in ALL AREAS, including areas with hot and humid weather.

questionText: Can cold weather and snow kill the new coronavirus?
answerText: There is no reason to believe that cold weather can kill the new coronavirus. The most effective way to protect yourself against the new virus is by cleaning your hands with with soap and water.

questionText: Does taking a hot bath prevent the new coronavirus disease?
answerText: Taking a hot bath will not prevent you from catching COVID-19. Your normal body temperature remains around 36.5°C to 37°C, regardless of the temperature of your bath or shower. You should avoid taking too hot of a shower as it can burn you. The best way to protect yourself against COVID-19 is by frequently cleaning your hands. By doing this you eliminate viruses that may be on your hands and avoid infection that could occur by then touching your eyes, mouth, and nose.

questionText: Can the new coronavirus be transmitted through mosquito bites?
answerText: To date there has been no information nor evidence that the virus occurs because of mosquitoes. The new virus spreads mostly through droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or through saliva or discharge from the nose. To protect yourself, clean your hands as much as you can with with soap and water or an alcohol based hand rub. Also, avoid close contact with anyone who is coughing and sneezing.

questionText: Are hand dryers effective in killing the new coronavirus?
answerText: Hand dryers alone are not effective in killing the 2019-nCoV. Cleaning your hands is more improtant. To protect yourself against the new coronavirus, you should frequently clean your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand rub if soap and water are not available. Once your hands are cleaned, you should dry them thoroughly by using paper towels or a warm air dryer.

questionText: Can an ultraviolet disinfection lamp kill the new coronavirus on skin?
answerText: UV lamps should not be used to clean hands or other areas of skin as UV radiation can cause rashes. Do not use medications or therapies outside of their intended use.

questionText: How effective are thermal scanners in detecting people infected with the new coronavirus?
answerText: Thermal scanners detect fevers  (i.e. have a higher than normal body temperature). Every specific thermal scanner will have different levels of effectiveness in detecting a fever. You should check with the manufacturer to determine the specific level of efficacy for a given scanner.   However, they cannot detect people who are infected but are not yet sick with fever. It takes between 2 and 10 days before people who are infected become sick and develop a fever.

questionText: Can spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body kill the new coronavirus?
answerText: Spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body will not kill viruses that have already entered your body. Additionally, several of these sprays can be toxic to your skin and can cause rashes or chemical burns. You should carefully read the use and warning label on any product before using it on your body. Do not use household cleaners on your skin and do not eat or drink household cleaners.

questionText: Can regularly rinsing your nose with saline help prevent infection with the new coronavirus?
answerText: There is no evidence at this time that rinsing the nose with saline protects people from infection. You should avoid irritating the skin inside your nose as it can make it more susceptible to infections.

questionText: Can eating garlic help prevent infection with the new coronavirus?
answerText: Garlic is a healthy food, but there is no evidence that eating garlic has benefits in preventing against the new coronavirus.

questionText: Are people contagious before they develop symptoms?
answerText: The current understanding is that individuals can be contagious before they develop symptoms.

questionText: What is community mitigation?
answerText: Community mitigation are activities communities take in response to outbreaks. These activities limit the spread of virus. It includes:                                                                              Personal activities like staying home, covering coughs and sneezes and washing hands.  Community strategies like school closures, postponing social gatherings and social distancing.  Environmental activities like cleaning of frequently touched surfaces and objects in homes, schools, workplaces.

questionText: What is the definition of close contact?
answerText: Close contact is defined as: a. Being within 6 feet (2 meters) of someone with COVID-19. Close contact can occur while caring for, living with, visiting, or sharing a health care waiting area or room with someone with COVID-19.  – or – b. Having direct contact with infectious body fluids of a COVID-19 case (e.g., being coughed on).

questionText: Is it dangerous to be outdoors?
answerText: You must check your local government policies to see if its acceptable for individuals to go outside for non-essential needss. If you do go outside, it is important to continue social distancing behaviors and aavoid close contact with other individuals by maintaing a 6-foot distance with others. If you are age 60 or over or have an underlying health condition, be extra careful about being around others.

questionText: What is convalescent plasma?
answerText: Convalescent plasma is the liquid part of blood that is taken from patients who are no longer sick.  [[Would you like more information about Why is convalescent plasma being investigated to treat COVID-19?]]

questionText: Why is convalescent plasma being investigated to treat COVID-19?
answerText: Convalescent plasma is being tested because there is no approved treatment for COVID-19 and there is some information that it might help some patients get better from COVID-19. More research is needed to see if it helps patients.

questionText: I recently recovered from COVID-19, can I donate convalescent plasma?
answerText: You may donate convalescent plasma if you have recovered and are eligible to donate blood. You must be symptom free for 14 days before donating.

questionText: Will Miracle Mineral Solution (MMS) cure COVID-19?
answerText: Antibiotics like Miracle Mineral Solution (MM) do not work against viruses and they only work on bacterial infections.

questionText: Do vaccines against pneumonia protect you against the new coronavirus?
answerText: Vaccines against pneumonia do not provide protection against the new coronavirus. The virus is so new and different that it needs its own vaccine. Vaccines against respiratory illnesses are highly recommended to protect your health.

questionText: What should people do if they think they may have been infected?
answerText: People who think they may have been exposed should call a health care professional if they have any of the symptoms.

questionText: Do health workers know how to take samples correctly from patients?
answerText: Yes. Sample collection for COVID-19 is similar to procedures that hospitals and healthcare workers follow for respiratory viruses. Laboratories have developed kits and guidance to ensure proper collection and shipping of samples.

questionText: What does it mean if someone is being monitored for COVID-19?
answerText: Public health monitors the health of people who could have been exposed to the virus.  Local health department staff contact the individual, assess their risk and supervise daily for health monitoring (temperature, cough, difficulty breathing) for 14 days after their last day of exposure.

questionText: Are there enough tests for COVID-19?
answerText: Some areas may currently be experiencing a shortage of COVID-19 tests. If you suspect you have been exposed to COVID-19 or that you may have COVID-19, you should contact your health care provider to determine if a test is recommended. In the meantime, even if you are not tested, you should stay at home and self-isolate or self-monitor.  [[Would you like to hear more about What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?]]

questionText: If I spray chlorine or alcohol on my skin, will it kill the viruses in my body?
answerText: Spraying chlorine, alcohol, or other substances on your body will not kill viruses inside your body.

questionText: If I am able to hold my breath for 10 seconds, does that mean I don't have COVID-19?
answerText: While shortness of breath is a symptom of COVID-19, holding your breath for 10 or more seconds is not a test for COVID-19. This should not be used in place of a COVID-19 test to determine whether or not you have COVID-19.

questionText: Where can I buy hand sanitizer?
answerText: Many stores and pharmacies sell hand sanitizers. We understand that many stores have run out of hand sanitizers and they may be hard to find. It is not recommended to buy homemade hand sanitizer from friends or other non-approved sources.

questionText: Can I make my own hand sanitizer?
answerText: It is not recommend to make your own hand sanitizer. If made incorrectly, hand sanitizer will not work, and there have been reports of skin burns from homemade hand sanitizer.

questionText: Should you disinfect your packages?
answerText: The CDC currently does not recommend santiizing your packages but if wish, you may use surface cleaners on your packages. Most important, wash your hands frequently and avoid close contact with people.

questionText: What are the general recommendatiosn for routine cleaning and disinfection of households with People Isolated in Home Care (e.g. Suspected/Confirmed to have COVID-19)?
answerText: Family members should educate themselves about COVID-19 symptoms and preventing the spread of COVID-19 in homes. Clean and disinfect high touch surfaces daily in common areas (e.g. tables, chairs, doorknobs, light switches, phones, tablets, touch screens, remote controls, keyboards, handles, desks, toilets, sinks) In the bedroom and bathroom for an ill person: consider only cleaning their room as-needed (e.g., soiled items and surfaces) to avoid unnecessary contact with the ill person. As much as possible, an ill person should stay in a specific room and away from other people in their home. The caregiver can provide personal cleaning supplies for an ill person’s room and bathroom, unless the room is occupied by child or another person for whom such supplies would not be right. These supplies include tissues, paper towels and cleaners. If a separate bathroom is not available, the bathroom should be cleaned and disinfected after each use by an ill person. If this is not possible, the caregiver should wait as long as possible after use by an ill person to clean and disinfect the high touch surfaces.

questionText: How do I clean and disfect electronics?
answerText: For electronics such as cell phones, tablets, touch screens, remote controls, and keyboards, follow the instructions on the device for all cleaning and disinfection of products. Consider use of covers for electronics. If there are no instructions available, consider the use of alcohol based wipes or sprays with at least 70% alcohol to clean touch screens. Dry surfaces all the way.

questionText: How do I clean and disinfect linens, clothing, and other items that go in the laundry?
answerText: Wear gloves when handling dirty laundry from an ill person and then discard after each use. If using reusable gloves, those gloves should be only used for cleaning and disinfecting surfaces for COVID-19 and should not be used for other household purposes. Clean hands right after gloves are removed. If no gloves are used when handling dirty laundry, be sure to wash hands afterwards. If possible, do not shake dirty laundry. This will minimize the chance of dispersing virus through the air. Launder items as appropriate in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions. If possible, launder items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from an ill person can be washed with other people’s items. Clean and disinfect clothes hampers according to guidance above for surfaces. If possible, consider placing a bag liner that is either disposable (can be thrown away) or can be laundered.

questionText: What are ways to manage anxiety about Coronavirus?
answerText: Get your facts straight. It’s important to stay up-to-date with the latest news from trusted sources regarding COVID-19. Be careful about what you read on the internet, especially comments and articles that are being shared via social media.   Keep things in perspective. Although you’ll want to stay informed about COVID-19, it’s important to focus on what you can control. Take a break from media coverage or social media if you find yourself panicking about the news or an article you just read online. If talking endlessly about coronavirus is upsetting to you, change the topic of conversation when you can. Be mindful and self-aware. Not everyone you come in contact with has been exposed to COVID-19. Although caution and preventative measures are extremely important right now, not everyone who coughs has the virus. Being self-aware is a big component of easing public anxiety. Focus on what you can do. Try to keep some normalcy. It can be hard with trips and events being cancelled, schools being closed and the concept of “social distancing” always at the top of your mind. But it’s important to try to maintain some sort of schedule. Routine makes most people, especially children, feel safe. Try to keep your normal sleep and meal times and focus on activities that make you feel happy – like reading a book, watching your favorite show or playing a board game with your family. Or take a walk, as long as you’re not in quarantine, a little fresh air is always a good idea!
topic: COVID-19 How to Protect Yourself / Your Family / Your Community

questionText: What are the best cleaners to remove coronavirus germs?
answerText: It is important to clean and disinfect frequently touched places on a normal basis. Soap and water can be used to clean surfaces. Use household bleach, alcohol solutions with at least 70% alcohol, or common household products, which are effective in killing this virus.

questionText: Will healthcare workers be more isolated because they are exposed to the virus on a daily basis?
answerText: Healthcare workers must monitor their health closely and practice all hygiene and infection control protocols. This is true especially if they are exposed to people with COVID-19. Many healthcare workers are choosing to self-isolate from their families to keep them safe and reduce their risk.  In addition to being physically isolated, lots of healthcare workers are feeling mentally isolated and stressed during this time. Would you like to hear more about [[how can healthcare workers manage their stress during COVID-19?]]  Many healthcare workers tend to prioritize the needs of other people over their own. It is important that healthcare workers take time to practice self care and take care of their own mental health - especially during this time. Some examples of how to practice self care during and after work include:

questionText: Should I visit my parents in a senior home?
answerText: You should not visit a senior home and it is likely that senior homes are not allowing visitors at this time. This is because a lot of people at the senior home are probably at high risk due to age and underlying health conditions. You might be able to talk with your family over the phone or with a video call. For other information or options, you should contact the senior home to find out how they are handling the COVID-19 response and how you can talk to your family.

questionText: What can I do during quarantine?
answerText: Most people are not used to being at home all the time. Many people feel bored or unsure of what to do during quarantine. Some things to do during quarantine include:  -reading (e-books and audiobooks are good options if you do not have physical books at home) -finding a new hobby, like an art project -learning to cook a new meal -talking on the phone or having video calls with friends or family  If it is allowed in your area, you may be able to go for walks outside as long as you practice social distancing. Experts also recommend having a set routine during the day, such as having set mealtimes and bedtimes.

questionText: There are no cleaning supplies at the store - what should I do?
answerText: You may have had trouble finding cleaning supplies at the stores lately. If there are no cleaning supplies at stores near you, you may decide to ask store employees when they expect their shelves to be restocked and try shopping around that time. You may also be able to order supplies online.   [[Would you like more information about What types of cleaning products should I use to protect against COVID-19?]]

questionText: Will my parents be at risk if I visit them?
answerText: Every situation is different, but in general, it is recommended to only be around people who you are living with. You should follow the recommended quarantine guidance from authorities where you live and keep your parents' health status in mind. If you are not able to see family in person, you may be able to talk on the phone, have video calls, or send them letters.

sourceName: JHU Public Health https://www.nytimes.com/article/coronavirus-hand-sanitizer-home-made-diy.html  answer also copied from from Also, what to do if you have no access to sanitizing wipes (Info sheet)
questionText: Can vodka be used as a hand sanitizer?
answerText: Vodka typically does not include enough alcohol to be an effective hand sanitizer. Make sure any hand santizer you have has at least 60% alcohol, as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Any hand sanitizer that has less than 60% alcohol will not be effective at killing the virus.   If you don't have access to hand sanitizer, soap and water are always the best option.

questionText: Can you recover from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19)?
answerText: Catching the new coronavirus DOES NOT mean you will have it for life. Most of the people who catch COVID-19 can recover and eliminate the virus from their bodies. If you catch the disease, make sure you treat your symptoms. If you have cough, fever, and difficulty breathing, seek medical care early – but call your health facility by telephone first. Most patients recover thanks to supportive care.

questionText: Does being able to hold your breath for 10 seconds or more without coughing or feeling discomfot mean you are free from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) or any other lung disease?
answerText: No. The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are dry cough, tiredness and fever. Some people may develop more severe forms of the disease, such as pneumonia. The best way to confirm if you have  the virus producing COVID-19 disease is with a laboratory test.  You cannot confirm it with this breathing exercise, which can even be dangerous.

questionText: What actions should businesses take to prepare for community spread of COVID-19?
answerText: Employers should consider following strategies to prevent spread of illness: • Encourage sick employees to stay home.  Ensure consistency of policies with public health guidance. • Separate employees with respiratory illness. • Clean frequently touched surfaces. • Provide information to employees before traveling

questionText: Do I need to close my business if a positive case of COVID-19 has been identified?
answerText: It is not necessary to close your business, but perform a thorough cleaning. • Clean all frequently touched surfaces including workstations, counter tops, doorknobs, and elevator buttons. • Use cleaning agents that are as per industry standards and follow the directions on the label.

questionText: What types of jobs or workplaces are considered essential during the shelter in place order?
answerText: Businesses will be required to hold in-person operations:  • Workers should not leave their homes. Only workers who work in essential services can leave. • Businesses decide who meet these criteria  • Businesses that remain open must take protective measures  • Examples of jobs or workplaces allowed remaining open include:  • grocery stores • hospitals and mobile emergency units • doctor’s offices  • utility companies • law enforcement • banks and credit unions • gas stations

questionText: How do I know if I am essential? Will my employer tell me?
answerText: Businesses and operations decide who meet those criteria and notify the workers.

questionText: Can pregnant women with COVID-19 pass the virus to their fetus or newborn?
answerText: No evidences show that virus can pass from mother to fetus before delivery. A report looked at nine pregnant women in China in their third trimester with pneumonia caused by COVID-19. None of the mothers developed severe illness. Two babies did show some signs of distress, but all nine babies were born alive and healthy. Also, they all tested negative for coronavirus.

questionText: Does COVID-19 have a different impact on women in their first trimester as opposed to their second or third trimester?
answerText: Unfortunately, we do not know. High fevers in early pregnancy generally can increase the risk of birth defects, but the effect of COVID-19 on women and their developing babies in early pregnancy is still unclear. There is so much that is unknown about how COVID-19  affects pregnancy.

questionText: Will there be animal food shortages?
answerText: There are no nationwide shortages of animal food. Certain foods at your grocery store might be low or sold out in some cases.

questionText: What should I do if my pet or other animals seem ill and I think it might be COVID-19?
answerText: There have not been any reports of pets or other animals becoming sick with COVID-19 in the United States.  If your animal seems ill, you should contact your vet just like you would for any other problem. In order to be sure the vet is ready for your pet, you should call ahead and arrange the hospital or clinic visit. Follow the animal hospital’s advice on proper safety before coming in.

questionText: If my pet has been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, do they need to be quarantined? If so, for how long?
answerText: There is no evidence that pets can get sick from COVID-19. You may wish to keep distance your pet for the same amount of time as people are being asked to keep distance - 14 days.

questionText: Are there any approved products that can prevent or treat COVID-19 in animals?
answerText: Animals are not likely to get COVID-19.

questionText: Do animals get their own type of coronaviruses?
answerText: Some types of coronaviruses cause flu-like sickness in humans, while others cause sickness in some types of animals.

questionText: If my pet previously had a species-specific coronavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19?
answerText: There have been no reports of pets or other animals becoming sick with COVID-19 as of now.  There is no data to suggest that another strain of coronavirus would cause your pet to get COVID-19.

questionText: If my pet has been vaccinated for a species-specific cornavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19?
answerText: There have been no reports of pets or other animals becoming sick with COVID-19 as of now.  There is no data to suggest that another strain of coronavirus would cause your pet to get COVID-19.

questionText: My pet has health problems and goes to the vet regularly for treatment. Should I be doing anything different to manage their health during the COVID-19 outbreak?
answerText: You should be careful just like you would if you were going to any other public place. If you are concerned about your own health or that of your pet when going to the veterinarian, contact their office first.

questionText: Is it true that veterinarians cannot get supplies like surgical gowns, gloves and masks?
answerText: Personal protective equipment (PPE) for human healthcare professionals is very important. PPE is needed in person to person settings, and may cause a lack in other health care settings.

questionText: What if my family member traveled from a country or had a layover in a country with widespread or sustained transmission in the last 14 days?
answerText: Your family member should:  Seek medical care right away. Before they go to a doctor’s office or emergency room, call ahead and tell them about their recent travel and symptoms. Avoid contact with others. Not travel while sick. They should cover their mouth and nose with a tissue or their sleeve (not their hands) when coughing or sneezing. Wash hands often with soap and water for 15-20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.

questionText: Is the U.S. food supply safe?
answerText: There is no evidence right now that food or food packaging causes COVID-19.  It is possible that the virus can live on surfaces or objects. It is important to follow the 4 key steps of food safety — clean, separate, cook, and chill. If you are worried about your food or food packaging, wash your hands after touching food, after removing food from the packaging, before you make food for eating and before you eat.

questionText: Is the U.S. animal food supply safe?
answerText: Currently there is no evidence of animal food or food packaging causing COVID-19.  SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19, is a virus that causes respiratory illness. Foodborne exposure to this virus is not known to be a route of transmission.

questionText: Should I invite my friends or neighbors over for dinner right now?
answerText: During this time, it is best to continue social distancing and avoid close contact with indivdiuals that do not live in your household as other they could be asymptomatic carriers of the virus.

questionText: Will there be food shortages?
answerText: There are no nationwide shortages of food, although in some cases certain foods at your grocery store might be low sometimes before stores can restock. Food production and manufacturing are throughout the U.S. and there are currently no disruptions reported in the supply chain. FDA is closely monitoring the food supply chain for any shortages in collaboration with industry and our federal and state partners.

questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from a food worker handling my food?
answerText: There is no evidence right now of food or food packaging causing COVID-19. Anyone handling, preparing and serving food should always follow safe food handling procedures, such as washing hands and surfaces often.

questionText: Should food workers who are ill stay home?
answerText: CDC recommends that employees who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness stay home and not come to work until they are free of fever (100.4° F [37.8° C] or greater using an oral thermometer), signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours, without the use of fever-reducing or other symptom-altering medicines (e.g. cough suppressants). Employees should notify their supervisor and stay home if they are sick.

questionText: Should food facilities (grocery stores, manufacturing facilities, restaurants, etc.) perform any special cleaning or sanitation procedures for COVID-19?
answerText: CDC recommends routine cleaning of all frequently touched surfaces in the workplace. Use the cleaning products that are usually used in these areas and follow the directions on the label.

questionText: Since restaurant workers and other service industry employees have ongoing contact with the public, are there any special precautions these workers should take to avoid becoming sick with a respiratory illness, such as wearing masks?
answerText: CDC does not recommend that people who are well wear a face mask to protect themselves from respiratory diseases, including COVID-19. Face masks should be used by people who show symptoms of COVID-19 to help prevent the spread of the disease to others. The use of face masks is also crucial for health workers and people who are taking care of someone with COVID-19 in close settings.  CDC recommends everyday preventive actions for everyone:  Avoid close contact with people who are sick. Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth. Stay home when you are sick. Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash. Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing. If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Always wash hands with soap and water if hands are visibly dirty.

questionText: Do I need to disinfect things I buy like groceries and supplies?
answerText: There is currently no evidence that supports the idea that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can survive on hard surfaces for up to 72 hours, shoppers may consider disinfecting food packaging after bringing it home from the store, in addition to common-sense measures like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionText: What precautions should I take at the supermarket?
answerText: If you believe you have been exposed to COVID-19, or if you are at high risk of symptoms, you should not go to the grocery store. Depending on where you traveled to, your local or national government may recommend that you stay quarantine for a period after recent travel.

questionText: Why are blood centers not testing donors for SARS-CoV-2 in the United States?
answerText: Someone who has symptoms of COVID-19 is not healthy enough to donate blood. The screening processes already in place will mean that someone with these symptoms will not be allowed to donate.

questionText: I Got A Call, Text, Or Email Saying I Could Get Financial Help. Is It Legitimate?
answerText: There have been reports that scammers pretend to be the government. They contact people by robocall, text message, email and other outreach. These scammers say they can get people financial help during the pandemic, and then ask for money or personal information, like your bank account or credit card number. This is scam.

questionText: Should I Worry About Hantavirus?
answerText: No. The main way hantavirus spreads to people is through infected mice and rats. It is possible to catch hantavirus from another person, but it’s very rare. For more information about hantavirus, visit the CDC’s website.
